capacity_payment.notes: Program states customers are paid based on electricity reduction compared to normal usage, but specific $/kW-month or $/kW rates are not publicly disclosed. Contact CPS Energy account manager for rates.

performance_payment.conditions: Payment based on electricity reduction during conservation events compared to normal usage baseline
performance_payment.notes: My Business Rewards DR (separate small business program) offers $70-73 per kW per season depending on notification option

bill_credit.structure: Credits applied based on performance during events

event_types.description: Called when statewide power demand is highest

eligibility.notes: Separate program available for small businesses (My Business Rewards DR) and residential battery storage (My Battery Rewards)

baseline_methodology: not specified - customer reduction compared to normal usage, specific CBL calculation methodology not disclosed in public materials

program_contacts.notes: Customers should contact their CPS Energy account manager for specific rates and enrollment

battery_suitability.justification: CPS Energy has a separate residential battery storage program (My Battery Rewards, $10 per event) but no publicly documented commercial/industrial behind-the-meter battery storage participation pathway for demand response. Payment structure unclear for commercial DR participants. Battery storage systems could technically participate by discharging during events to reduce net load, but: (1) no explicit mention of battery eligibility in commercial DR materials, (2) payment rates not publicly disclosed making ROI analysis impossible, (3) unclear if battery discharge qualifies under baseline methodology, (4) residential-only battery program suggests commercial batteries may not be eligible or have different pathway. Limited rating due to lack of clarity on commercial battery participation and undisclosed payment rates.

alternative_revenue_streams.notes: As an ERCOT utility, commercial customers with large battery systems may be able to participate in ERCOT wholesale markets (ancillary services, energy arbitrage) in addition to or instead of utility DR program. This would require registration as a Resource Entity with ERCOT.

my_business_rewards_dr.bonus_hours: $10 per kW for 16 additional evening events (7-10 PM)

my_battery_rewards.eligibility: residential customers only with owned BESS

strategic_context.utility_goal: 410 MW of incremental demand reduction by 2027
strategic_context.utility_battery_projects: CPS Energy deploying 400+ MW of utility-scale battery storage (Padua 1: 50 MW, Padua 2: 150 MW, Ferdinand: 200 MW)
strategic_context.market_context: ERCOT territory with energy scarcity events and high price volatility creating strong value proposition for demand flexibility

research_notes: CPS Energy operates three distinct demand response programs: (1) Commercial/Industrial DR with undisclosed rates requiring account manager contact, (2) My Business Rewards DR for small businesses with transparent seasonal rates of $70-73/kW, and (3) My Battery Rewards for residential battery owners at $10/event. The commercial DR program documentation is notably opaque on payment rates, minimum participation thresholds, baseline methodology, and battery storage eligibility. The existence of a separate residential-only battery program suggests commercial batteries may not be eligible for the standard commercial DR program, or may have an undocumented participation pathway. The small business program provides clearer rate information ($70-73 per kW per season) which may serve as a proxy for commercial rates. Key information gaps: commercial payment rates, minimum kW requirement, explicit battery eligibility, baseline calculation method, and whether dual participation in ERCOT wholesale markets is allowed. CPS Energy's aggressive utility-scale battery deployment (400+ MW) demonstrates grid storage value, but customer-sited commercial battery pathway remains unclear.
research_quality_notes: Medium quality - confirmed program is active with good details on event parameters (25 events/season, 3 hours, 2hr or 30min notice, June-Sept), notification methods, and contact information. However, critical commercial payment rates are not publicly disclosed (major gap), no minimum participation threshold specified, baseline methodology not documented, and commercial battery storage eligibility completely unclear. Small business program rates provide some reference point. Multiple documentation sources attempted but key PDFs not readable/accessible via web scraping.
